1111121121121212222211111122122112211112.content:
You were bored to the point of distraction. You clearly saw this class as a grand waste of time since you have already done this stuff. You hardly paid attention as you looked outside the window to see what interesting thing was there to see. The only thing you saw was the caretaker tending to hedging in a section of the school yard. Your eyes focused on him as he carefully pruned the leaves from the shrubbery that have grown unkempt. He seemed quite diligent and hardworking. I wonder how long he has been working out there?, you thought. What other things does he do all day besides tending to plants?, you wondered. You continued to watch as the old caretaker ambled to another section of the hedge and with pruners in hand, started to trim the other side of the green line of shrubbery.

You were deep in thought that you did not notice that the room had gone quiet. No talking from the teacher, Miss Summers, and not a sound from the class. "Jasmine Storms!", Miss Summers called. You snapped out of your distracted thoughts and looked around to see that all eyes were on you and that Miss Summers was peeved at your failure to respond to her.

"Jasmine, I expect you to pay full attention here in class! You certainly have no time to look through windows at anything outside while I am conducting class!", Miss Summers scolded. You casted your eyes down in embarrassment as the teacher let you have her caustic tongue. "Do you consider what we are doing here a waste of your time Miss Storms?", Miss Summers continued. Giggles from the class greeted this sarcasm. You were becoming more uncomfortable. "Have you got better things to do than pay attention to what is being taught here, Miss Jasmine Storms?" Miss Summer asked, her cheeks getting red with anger. You muttered, "N-n-no Miss Summers." More giggles.

"Since you obviously already know everything in this text book, you get right up here and take over the class. Read and let these, your unenlightened classmates, have the benefit of your superior wisdom!", the teacher said, clearly annoyed at your show of disinterest. You tried hard to suppress the laughter rising to your throat. If only she knew that indeed, you already knew all there is to know from that phonics text book! It was an updated edition to the same one you used eleven years ago when you were in kindergarten. You managed to keep a straight face as you slowly made your way to the front of the class.

Miss Summers handed you the text book and stepped aside, so now you were standing in front where the teacher would normally stand. All the children were looking at you expectantly. You opened the book and started to read...rapidly like a sixteen year old who was not really interested in the words but must read them anyway. You flipped the page and continued reading at the same speed, not noticing that your teacher was wide eyed with shock and your classmates were speechless. You were on the sixth page when you suddenly felt the book being ripped from your hands and Miss Summers stood over you, her expression dark and ominous.

"What kind of joke do you think this is Miss Storms?", the teacher thundered. You looked at her and in a calm voice that surprised you, replied, "I just did what you told me to, I read to the class."

"Where did you learn to read like That? Oh don't bother answering that!", the teacher said. You stared at her, not knowing what she will say or do next. The children were chattering in excitement, "Jasmine can read! ....She can read!".

"OK young lady get back to your seat. I will have to give you something else to do while I attend to the others", Miss Summers said, her voice a lot calmer than it was just seconds ago. For the rest of the day, Miss Summers gave you other tasks to do , which were mainly puzzles and problem solving exercises.

Nothing else happened during the rest of the day that got you into trouble. At the end of school, however, you were only too happy to go home.

1111121121121212222211111122122112211112.content:
Later back home, you were in your room playing video games as the others were not yet back from school and mom was the only other person home. Mom was however busy on her laptop downstairs so there was little conversation between you. You were still playing the video game when you heard voices downstairs. You put the game down and went downstairs, wondering who could be speaking to your mom. The voice was that of a man, which sounded vaguely familiar.

As you crept closer to the family room, you realized that the voices were actually at the front door and not in the room at all. Why wouldn't mom let the person in? you thought.

"Why should we believe you this time?", mom asked coldly.

"Because, Mrs. Storms, I am telling you the absolute truth, and besides why else would we come all the way here?", the male voice responded.

You froze as you saw that the man at the door was Dr. Hanson from the Genetics Facility. You also saw that there was a second man with him, someone you had not seen before.

"What's going on mom?", you asked.

"Jazz, these gentlemen were about to leave...", mom replied.

"Actually Mrs. Storms, we are here to check up on the progress of your son, since the, uuhhmm, little accident...", Dr. Hanson said. The other man shifted his briefcase from one hand to the other, and cleared his throat.

"Pardon the poor manners of Dr. Hanson, I am Donald Wainwright, from Wainwright and Partners..", he said, extending his hand. Mom did not shake it.

"Very well then..", the tall, thin man in the tan suit said as he lowered his hand. "What Dr. Hanson needs to tell you is that we have been retained to ensure that no harm comes to the Genetics Facility as a result of the, ....shall we say, "little accident" with your daughter."

Mom looked at Dr. Hanson then at Mr. Wainwright, her anger growing.

"So, Dr. Hanson, you have retained the services of lawyers, to do what exactly?", she asked icily.

"Uuhhm, ........Mrs. Storms, you have to understand our position, we know how hurt you may be because of what had happened to your son and the fact that we are unable to reverse it...", he said.

"Are you afraid I would sue your ass??!!", mom hissed.

Mr. Wainwright interjected, "What my client has instructed is that we do everything to prevent anything that will negatively affect the good name of the Genetics Facility, so if it means preventing a lawsuit, then that's what will happen..."

"You have some nerve!", mom shot back. "Look at what your so called "accident" has done to my child !, Just look !", mom was livid.

"You think I wanted this??!! Do you think the Genetics Facility has enough money to pay for the damage caused by its carelessness and experimentation??", mom's voice was getting louder with anger.

"Mrs. Storms, .....Mrs. Storms, let me assure you that...", Mr. Wainwright started, but mom slammed into him, "You better think carefully what you are saying to me right now!".

"Uuuhhm, ......we better get going...", Dr. Hanson said to Mr. Wainwright, "...it's clear we won't get anywhere with Mrs. Storms right now...", he said.

"You're damn right you won't. How dare you come here with your lawyer, trying to get me to shut up about what happened to my child! You better be damn well advised that I intend to take action against you for this negligence!", she raged.

"You may certainly go ahead and take any action you choose Mrs. Storms, but be prepared for a mighty long fight. We won't roll over and quit, not by a long shot.", Mr. Wainwright said, as he turned on his heals and strode away. Dr. Hanson followed.

"Mom, what are you going to do now?", you asked anxiously.

Mom tightened her fists to stop her hands from trembling, and through gritted teeth replied....

"My sister likes playing with it and i wanna surprise her" you said. As you turned around to bounce the ball, you felt something tug at your hair and Lily yelling, "Leave her alone." You turned again as saw that one of the boys had grabbed you by your hair and was trying to take your ball.

You struggle, dodging the boy's attempts to snatch the ball from your hands, until he grunts in frustration and pulls hard on your hair. You yelp in pain and tears begin to form in your eyes, but at the same time anger wells up inside you. No way are you getting pushed around by a kid.

"Let me go!" you demand before throwing yourself backwards into the boy. Surprised by your sudden display of force, he stumbles and lets go of you. You take a few quick steps away before turning to face him, holding the ball against your chest.

"Stupid girl!" he spits. "Gimme my ball!"

"It's not yours!" you retort.

"I said give it!" he says as he picks up a piece of gravel and throws it, hitting you in the hand.

"Ow!" you exclaim, out of annoyance more than pain. "Fine, have it!" you shout. You hoist the ball above your head and hurl it at the boy with as much force as your little arms can muster. It hits him in the jaw and he falls over backward with a scream.

The boy sits on the ground and begins to cry, his belligerent attitude having evaporated. You bite your lip and shift your gaze to see Lily staring at you in disbelief. Great, you just assaulted a child. You look around in a growing panic and find that most of the other kids have silently turned their attention to you as well. You let out a small gasp when you see the teacher - Miss Summers, you think her name was - approaching you.

"What's going on over here?" she demands.

"Teacher!" the boy wails. "She hit me with the ball!"

"Jasmine?" the teacher accusingly addresses you.

"He started it!" you desperately argue, knowing it won't do you much good.

"Two wrongs don't make a right, Jasmine," she sternly tells you. "And he didn't make you cry."

You're don't want to admit that he almost did. You glumly stare at your feet as Miss Summers continues to tell you off in front of the whole class. In all this time you've spent standing three foot something, you've never felt so small. Here you are at the mercy of a kindergarten teacher, praying she won't make you regret this any more than you already do.

Your heart sank. This was the last thing you needed, as if the day wasn't bad enough. Not only have you found yourself on the wrong side of the school's rules on your first day, you also realized that you really have not made many friends. The boy who had tried to bully you was sniffing softly and wiping away tears. Miss Summers knelt down to his eye level and said soothingly, "Jason, did Jasmine hurt you badly?"

The boy, Jason, sniffed a little louder and in almost a wail sobbed, "she hit me hard and I think my nose is broken..."

You were however upset and you felt your face flush with anger. Why should I apologize? you thought. If anything, they all should apologize to me. You knew these were irrational thoughts but at this moment you did not care. You pouted even harder as you fumed.

"Well, we are waiting.", Miss Summers demanded. Jason was sobbing softly, still putting on a show of being badly hurt. So you thought.

You really did not care anymore what happened here at kindergarten. As far as you were concerned today might as well be the last day you go to school here. You couldn't help but reflect that just a few days ago, you were Jasper "Jazz" Storms, sixteen years old high school student, already six foot one, and captain of your school's basket ball team. Now, on account of that stupid field trip, you have been reduced to a tiny little girl who is forced to relive kindergarten. This was not what you wanted. Hell, you missed your real friends, your popularity, and relative freedoms. You ruefully thought that if you were not returned to normal very soon, you will be forced to relive eleven years of your life while your friends grow into adulthood.

You muttered under your breath, "life sucks."

"What was that young lady?", Miss Summers demanded, her tone impatient. "You are really working yourself into a visit to the Principal's Office. Now let me hear that apology"

You looked defiantly at Miss Summers, and all the children around you. I rather be expelled than to apologize to that louse, you thought.

She stared at you as you waited and soon enough, you was let in. the Principal was a woman about 40 years old by the name of Jackson, and to your surprise, held a file on her desk clearly marked 'Jasmine Storms'.

"I was hoping not to see you so soon, young lady" Ms Jackson said staring at you. You gulped, realizing that she must had known all about you. Miss Summers though looked surprised. "What is going on? Why where you expecting her, Terri? Had she been expelled from other schools?"

"Not quite" Ms Jackson said. "This file should explain exerything. I thought it was complete nonsense when I first read it, but I am now convinced..." You stared in horror. While you hated the thought of being treated like a little girl, you hated the idea of everyone knowing that a youth serum turned you into a girl even more. "Pwease don't read that file. i'm sorry i hit you! It was an accident! I wasn't thinking..." you gulped, as you tried to reach the file first.

"What is she hiding?" Miss Summers wondered as she gave Ms Jackson a curious glance. Ms Jackson glanced at you grimly. "Miss Storms was the victim of an accident at a science lab and..."

"Pwease don't tell. I'll apologize to that lying prick that yanked my hair and tried to steal my ball" you said. "The girls saw it!"

"Could you leave us alone for a while?" Ms Jackson asked. Miss Summers nodded and walked out of the office puzzled. once alone, Ms Jackson turned to you. "I know things must be hard for you, Jazz. Bet you're wondering where I got this file telling me about what happened in the genetics lab? Anyway, it doesn't matter. 1111121121121212222211111122122112211112.content:
Later at home you were the center of attention. "How was your day?", asked Ella and Zoe. "Yeah, how was it?". James echoed. You gave a nonchalant response, not wishing to recount the full story of your terrible first day. The principal, Ms Jackson, had told Mom all about what had happened at recess and how you behaved afterwards. Needless to say, Mom was not pleased and it was all she could do not to let you have it there and then in the Principal's office. In the end, Mom agreed with the Principal not to have you expelled but to give you another chance to redeem yourself at the school. Your first "punishment" was to be a public apology in front of the entire class the next day. You were not looking forward to this.

After you settled in your room, with James doing homework at his desk and the girls in their room also doing homework, your phone rang. "H-Hello...?", you answered tentatively wondering who it could be.

"Hi, may I speak to Jasper?", asked the female voice on the other end, which you recognized as that of your girlfriend Chelsea's. "Hold on, I'll get him...", you replied.

Your mind raced. How can I talk to Chelsea without sounding every bit like a five year old?, you thought. You waited for what you thought was long enough for you to "get" yourself before continuing, "Hi Chelsea." You hoped that the voice you had adopted was deep enough to convince Chelsea that she was not talking to a five year old. You sounded more like someone with a bad case of the flu.

"Hi yourself, Jazz", she said. "You sound terrible, like you're down with the virus..."

"Y-yeah", you replied, relieved that she thought you had the flu. You coughed for emphasis before continuing, "...I'm so sick, hardly could get out of bed."

"Oooh, poor baby", she sympathized, "...I'll just come over to keep you company."

"No! No!...", you cried, a little too quickly. You hoped Chelsea did not pick up on this, but she did. "Oh!, ...you rather have that bitch Dianne come over instead of me, huh?"
Dianne was another girl in your school who was Chelsea's rival in everything including getting your attention. While admittedly you had done nothing to discourage Dianne's attentions, you had made it clear that Chelsea was your girl. Now, you did not like her accusation.

"No! No!...", you said lamely, trying hard to keep your voice from sounding like a five year old, "...it's just that the doctor has me under quarantine and I don't want to infect anyone else", you replied, mentally congratulating yourself for that quick save.

"Oh, OK", Chelsea said, a little placated. "Want me to email you what we got for homework today?" she asked.

"Yeah, send it..", you responded. Just then you heard a beep on the line signaling an incoming call. You quickly ended the call with Chelsea and picked up the other call. It was Nathan. After exchanging preliminaries including about your bout with the flu, you and your best friend had a long conversation.

The rest of the evening before dinner was spent on the phone. It seems that everyone missed you at school today and were calling to check up on you. Your friends were calling to to see how you were.

The next time the phone rang, you were a little cranky. You were exhausted after spending more than two hours holding conversation in a fake voice. You answered exasperated, "...Hello!...".

"Heya kid, how're you holding up...?", it was Harry, the detective. "I have some news for you so listen up...", he said."

At the sight of mom, you found that you couldn't say it; that Harry had no more leads and that you had little choice but to gow up again as little Jasmine Storms. You sat in front of your plate, which was considerably smaller than normal, unhappily wondering why all this happened to you.

"Kids..." mom said, her voice indicating that she wanted someone to talk.

"Mom. i'm not hungry" you said, pushing away your food. Ignoring their looks, especially mom's, you headed for your room, where you crashed down onto your bed and sobbed. you weren't too surprised to see mom walk in a few minutes later.

"James told me" mom said flatly. "Do you want to talk?"

"Not really" you said downcast. Mom glanced at you, wondering what to say. Finally she said, "When you want to, come and see me. Its not healthy for you to keep all this to yourself, Jasmine." You felt like screaming. She knew what was wrong, and you hated the fact that she seemed to be toying with you. However you said, "Okay mom." Mom shook her head as she left you alone.

Thirty minutes later, you lifted your head from your tear-stained pillow. It was Zoe and Ella, arguing about their new favorite topic; you. Annoyed, you sat up and listened in.

"I'm not being insensitive. i'm being realistic! Jasmine is a girl...." Ella yelled.

"And you're saying i'm not?" Zoe countered. "Not all girls go for pink dresses and ponies."

"i'm trying to make her comfortable. She'll thank me in a couple years..."

"Its totally different.." Ella yelled.

You turned over and buried your head in your pillow. You definately didn't need this.

You gasped in terror as you tried desperately to break your fall, but failed. You tried to scream, but no sound came out. Looking around in panic, you saw shapes, all dark and ominous. "Mommy!", you screamed breathlessly, but to your utter terror you saw first Doctor Hanson, then Doctor Blake, that detective Harry, Miss Summers, even the bully Jason holding pink dresses and mockingly chanting, "Jasmine, Jasmine, Jasmine Storms....". Your terror mounted when you saw Ella, Zoe and James among the jeering faces. "Jasmine!, Jasmine!..."

"...Jasmine!, wake up!", your Mom said, shaking you gently out of your sleep. You woke up startled, and as your eyes focused on the smiling face of Mom, you felt a wave of relief. What you were just experiencing was the worst nightmare you had ever had. "Oh Mommy..", you cried.

"Did you have a bad dream? I noticed you were fighting your sheets..", Mom said soothingly. You buried your head into Mom's breasts and for a long moment you did not want to let go.

"Honey", Mom continued, "remember you have school today so we must get dressed..."

You suddenly remembered that today was the day you must give an apology in front of the entire class. You must also face that bully, Jason again, to apologize. Your heart sank. "Mommy", you whimpered, "do I really have to go today, I wanna stay home..."

"No sweetie, remember what you must do, you have to go to school today.", Mom replied. "Come, let's get dressed..." With that she took you into the bathroom to get you ready for school.

____________________________________________________


You sat lower in your seat as all eyes were on you. The teacher, Miss Summers, made the dreaded announcement first thing as she entered the classroom and faced you.

"Children, we have with us again Jasmine Storms, who has something really important to say to you this morning. I want you all to give her a chance to say it by paying full attention. You all know what to do when someone gives an apology, do you?"

"Yes Miss Summers", the children all responded.

"OK, Jasmine, come right up front here and say your apology.", Miss Summers invited, indicating with her hands where you should stand.

Your stomach felt like lead and you felt queasy as though at any moment you would lose your breakfast. "I really need my mom right now", you thought desperately.

"We're waiting...", Miss Summers said, with more than a hint of impatience.

Standing shakily, your knees buckling, you slowly made your way toward the front of the room. With every step, you wished that Miss Summers would tell you to return to your seat and spare you the agony of this apology. You felt all twenty-eight pairs of eyes on you and heard the excited whispers of the children behind you. "Be quiet children!, Let us hear Jasmine...", Miss Summers said.

You turned to face the class and felt even more scared as all the children were leaning forward in their seats in anticipation of what you were about to say. The expression on Jason's face was one of smug triumph. You looked over to Lilith and saw that her face was etched with concern for you. You smiled despite your fear, but only briefly, as you tried to form the dreaded words.

"I-I-I'm s-s-sorry...", you stuttered, weakly, your voice barely audible.

"Can you all hear her class?", asked Miss Summers.

"No Miss Summers!", the children chorused.

"Come on now Jasmine, ....speak up.", Miss Summers demanded.

You gulped nervously and taking a deep breath, you began "I am sorry for what I did yesterday during break....", you paused, tears welling in your eyes, wishing that you did not have to do this.

"...I know that I was wrong...", your voice trembling, "I'm also sorry for hurting Jason...", you twisted your feet uncomfortably and wrung your hands in your dress..."I'm sorry for kicking Miss Summers and for the hurtful things I said...", tears streaming down your face, you really hated to do this, why did you have to apologize like this, in front of everyone??

"...and I promise not to do anything like these again...", you ended, a little rushed.

You were about to return to your seat, when Miss Summers held you and to your utter surprise, gave you a big hug. The children broke into spontaneous chatter, while Jason came up to where you were standing and also gave you a quick hug.

"You see, Jasmine, we must always take care how we relate to each other at school. We hope we can get along from now on and not have a repeat of your bad behavior.", Miss Summers said.

You returned to your seat, glad that this ordeal was over, but wondering how come Jason was not asked to apologize to you for his bullying attempt on you.

Later at break, Lilith and two of her friends joined you by the toy box and chatted as though your ordeal earlier this morning did not happen. You were happy for once to be in the company of friends.

As you struggled to put your clothes on, you could not help but think how badly you had lost control over yourself in the past few days. Now that you were a five year old, things you would have taken for granted, or could have done on your own, were no longer so clear cut. Just look how easily your younger sister, Ella, was able to strip you out of your clothes and force you into that silly ballerina outfit. Nothing you could do to prevent that, you thought wryly. Back when you were the sixteen year old bigger brother, Ella would not have dared to treat you like this, in fact she looked up to you. How quickly things have changed now that you were this vulnerable little girl.

You were then hit with a new realization about your current situation. It hit so hard, you gasped. When faced with a terrible or unfamiliar situation, such as the dreaded apology, you were literally a five year old! Nothing of your sixteen year old self was at the surface to take control. No wonder you behaved the way you did at school, you realized. Your mind reached back to when you practically behaved like a five year old, and concluded that the other occasions were at the play date with Lilith, your first day at kindergarten, and when Harry told you of his investigation's dead end. You realized that your behavior then was not like a rational teen and you wondered when will be the next time you will lose control again and how that will affect your behavior. "I'll need another dose of whatever treatment I got at that lab to control this", you said to yourself.

Ella returned, saying "Hey Jasmine, I have your girl friend Chelsea on the phone...".

Oh no!, you thought in dismay, Ella was serious when she went for the phone to call your friend. The last person you really wanted to speak to in this condition was your girlfriend. "Please tell her I'm not up, .... still sick with the flu...", you begged desperately.

"Oh no you won't get off that easily:", Ella said, handing you the phone. "...take it, or I'll press send, and your picture will go to all your friends on Facebook..."

You looked at Ella with the phone in her hand, her expression resolute to complete this humiliation and put you in your place. You could feel the now familiar panic rising and the beads of cold sweat on your forehead. Your breathing became rapid, as though you had ran flights of stairs, and you tried to speak, to tell Ella that now was not a good time to speak to anyone, but you only managed a squeak. Ella had not noticed your discomfort.

"Here Jazz, take the phone now!, Chelsea is still on the line!", Ella hissed urgently.

You winced, and your hands shook as you took the phone and tentatively answered....

"I guess it makes sense," Nathan muses, putting a hand to his chin, "In a world gone mad sort of way."

"I don't believe it. You're pranking us," Chelsea says, pointing an accusing finger at Ella.

"I'm not! It's the truth!" Ella protests.

"Then why are you so damn smiley, huh?" Chelsea counters. Good question, you think. Even Ella seems to fumble for an answer. Rather than wait for whatever crap she comes up with, you decide to speak up,

"It's really me, guys," you say. You lift your head and lock eyes with Chelsea, who studies you carefully. Ella taps her foot, wordlessly urging you to say something else, but you don't have to; Chelsea eventually melts under the puppy dog eyes you only faintly realise you're giving her.

"Oh, you poor thing," she says, kneeling down and putting a hand on your shoulder. "I don't know about this story, but I know sadness when I see it."

"Chelsea..." You gently throw yourself into her, turning her hold on you into a hug. It's an odd, conflicting experience. Last week you would have killed for an excuse to bury yourself in her cleavage like this, but now there's no attraction involved at all.

"Aww, isn't that sweet?" Ella coos.

"Shut up," you murmur into Chelsea's chest. Ella probably didn't hear the words, but you're sure she got the message.

Nathan shuffles his feet awkwardly before breaking back into the conversation. "So what's gonna happen? Are you trying to get some sort of treatment for this?"

"There's no antidote," Ella is eager to inform him.

"So what, that's it?" Nathan says. "You're a kid now? You have to start your life over?"

"Yeah," you wearily breathe before pushing yourself off of Chelsea. "Not everyone's as bad as her about it," you shoot a quick glare at Ella, "But yeah."

Nathan mutters something to himself while Chelsea stares at the floor, deep in thought. "What are we gonna do?" she asks.

"I don't know," you say, not really knowing what the question means. "You guys... you're still my friends, right?"

Chelsea seems to hesitate for a moment, but then, to your relief, she smiles warmly. "Of course, Jazz."

"Yeah, we can still hang out," Nathan says. "Well, kind of. I guess. I mean, yeah, I can come over and stuff."

You smile. While Nathan's fumbling sentiment reminds you that things will never be the same, a huge weight has been lifted from your mind.

And then Ella, who you had briefly forgotten was standing behind you, has to go and ruin the moment. "Well then! Everything's fine!" she beams. "So, Jasmine, I know a few games you could play..."

"Just go away!" you snap. Admittedly, you sort of owe her for pushing you to get this over with, but you really don't want to encourage her.

Ella frowns at you, and looks back and forth between you and your friends. "Oh, alright then," she sighs. She walks off to her room, grumbling to herself, "I guess I'll just leave my kid sister with the pair of teenagers I hardly know..."

"Wait!", you yelled as Ella was about to step through the door. "Do you really think that's a good idea, calling my friends?"

Ella paused and turned to you, "why, are you afraid of what they would do if they find out who you are now?", she asked, sarcastically.

Ella walked over and sat on the bed and buried her head in her hands, "Uuuuuuggggh!, I hate it when you're right!"

You walked over to Ella and took her hand, "Sis, listen....when I am ready, if the effect of this youth serum is still like this, I will tell my friends and anyone you like me to tell, but right now is not the best time. Just supposed the serum wears off tomorrow, imagine the embarrassment if the story is already out there that I'm a little girl..." You smiled reassuringly at your sister and in a familiar tone you had always used as a sixteen year old bigger brother, said, "You shouldn't act hastily and do anything you will regret. Lets wait on mom to come home. she'll know what to do."

"OK....", Ella replied, her tone subdued.

The room was quiet for a few minutes as you both were thinking of the situation and what was said. Suddenly Ella said, "But I need my doll. Please tell me where it is?"

You smiled, "I can do you one better. I'll get it for you." You skipped over to the closet and after rummaging among the clothes piled at the bottom, you pulled out Ella's doll from where you had hidden it, and handed it back to her.

Ella grabbed the doll and gave it a hug, "oohhh, thanks Jazz!", she squealed. To your surprise, Ella reached over and gave you a big hug. "Thank you!" You felt a little awkward but did not attempt to wriggle from her.

You heard voices downstairs. "Who could that be?", asked Ella, releasing you from the hug.

"Let's check and see...", you said, hoping it was mom and the others returning home. You both went downstairs and you were able to hear the voices from behind the closed front door. You ran to the door and threw it open and saw...

1111121121121212222211111122122112211112.content:
You open the door (a task that takes more effort than you'd like to admit) to see Mom, Zoe and James holding bags of shopping. But the three of them, especially James, seem taken aback at the sight of you, which confuses you until you realise... you're still wearing Ella's ballet outfit!

"Eep!" you cry with a jump, looking down at yourself.

Zoe shakes her head in exasperation as she walks into the house, lifting her bags over your head to get past you. "I'm not even gonna say anything."

Mom walks straight by you, biting her lip. Ella follows her, taking an interest in whatever the shopping bags contain, which worries you a little. As James closes the door, looking at you strangely, you briefly try to think of something to say, only for your embarrassment to overwhelm you and send you shooting back upstairs to the twins' room.

You wander over to Zoe's side of the room and stand holding all your muscles tense until you calm yourself down by returning your thoughts to the way you talked down Ella. It's comforting to think that just because you're little doesn't mean you can't still make yourself heard.

Zoe hesitantly walks in and looks at you with sad eyes, fidgeting awkwardly for a few moments until she gets herself to speak.

"I'm sorry, Jazz," she begins, walking closer to you. "We couldn't convince Mom it was a bad idea to..."

"Actually," you interrupt as you begin to extract yourself from the leotard, "It's okay. I think things are a little better between us now."

Zoe is momentarily stunned by your words. "What, 'cause you let her do what she wanted with you?" she asks, arching an eyebrow.

"No," you toss the leotard into a corner and start on untying the pink shoes, "Because I reasoned with her. I got her to back down."

"After letting her dress you up in her old ballet stuff," Zoe points out, unimpressed.

"Well, yeah," you say, stepping out of the shoes and approaching your clothes, "But still. Embarrassed as I am right now, I feel a lot better knowing I can still get her to listen to me." You pause for a second to mull over what you just said. "You know, I never quite realised how different I've been acting this whole time. Even aside from, you know, that."

Zoe cringes a little at the mention of "that" before replying, "I guess you have been kind of a pushover lately..." Her face shows immediate regret at her choice of words. "I mean, uh... sorry!"

"No, you're pretty much right," you sigh while mentally berating yourself for how appealing the little blue dress in your hands now looks after what you just had on.

"But I don't have the right to say it!" Zoe says. "I haven't been standing up to her either... I mean, she's been way more stubborn than usual, and I don't know how to deal with it..." As you wriggle into your dress, Zoe turns away and sighs deeply. "I feel so useless, Jazz. Your whole life is falling apart and all I can do is watch."

You look up at Zoe with concern. Well, at least this is another chance to work that big brother magic you thought you'd lost. "Zoe... sis... it means a lot just to have you around. I mean, well..." You can't believe you're about to say this, but... "I want to be like you when I grow up."

Zoe spins around to face you again, revealing her thoroughly bemused smile. "Jazz...?!"

"Well, I'd rather it didn't come to that," you smile and shrug, "But it made you feel better, right?"

Zoe chuckles quietly. "Okay, sure. But I still want to do more for you than just exist... I'll find something for the two of us to go out and do later in the week, okay? I think you need to get away from... basically everyone."

"That'd be nice," you say. "So what were you guys doing, anyway?"

"Oh, right..." Zoe glances at the door. "We picked up some stuff for your room... yeah, there's a reason we didn't bring Ella. There's still a few girly things in there just to keep up appearances, though. God knows that Lily girl is gonna show up here someday."

You frown, a little annoyed. "Don't I get a say in this?"

"That's what I said," Zoe shrugs apologetically, "But Mom said this was just to get you started. You might wanna talk to her right away if you want any input on the rest of it."

That reminds you, you need to talk to Mom about your friends as well. Ella was right about one thing: you can't claim to have the flu forever.

I see" mom said, sighing. "I really don't know what to do. Do you have any ideas?"

You was surprised to hear mom ask you for ideas, especially with your lack of say in anything of late. "No. Ella was going to just call one of them, but I convinced her it was a bad idea."

"She can be a little too impulsive" mom said, agreeing with you. "As for your friends, maybe its best to try and gauge their opinion by spending time with them without them knowing its you."

"its only a suggestion, miss" mom said. She paused and said mainly to herself, "Those 'scientists' have a lot to answer for."

1111121121121212222211111122122112211112.content:
You return upstairs to the worrying sight of half your stuff cluttering up the lobby. You rush into your room to find James and Zoe going at your walls with paintbrushes, painting over the green with a light yellow colour. "Oh, come on!" you shout.

"Sorry, dude," James half-heartedly offers. You don't quite feel comfortable discussing this with him, so you move to get Zoe's attention instead.

"Just be glad it's not pink," she says. "I told you, we need to keep up appearances."

You look around and notice that your bed, which has been moved to the middle of the room, is currently home to a handful of stuffed animals and... is that a dollhouse? Blech. For some reason, you walk up to the bed and pull yourself onto your tiptoes to take a closer look. "Can't I have the appearance of a girl who doesn't keep stuff like this around?"

"I think that went out the window when you made friends with the girliest little brat since Ella," Zoe says, looking a little guilty. "And I guess that wasn't really anyone's fault, in the end... but I'm sorry I couldn't keep you out of skirts."

You pull at the bottom of your dress, realising you haven't thought much of your clothes in a while, at least not while wearing them. "You know, I'm kind of used to them already..."

Zoe stops painting to give a strange look that makes you regret your admission. "Jazz... if I can ask, what do you do at kindergarten? Like, during breaks and stuff?"

You reluctantly decide to answer the question. "Eh, I dunno... I just hang around, pretend to care about dolls and stuff. I don't try very hard, but they're just kids. They don't really notice."

"Hmm," Zoe glances away at nothing in particular before turning back to the wall. "If you don't wanna be stuck with this image, you need to start changing it at some point. Just do it slowly, make it look realistic. Take an interest in playing tag or something and just go from there, you know?"

Rather than give much thought to that now, you turn your attention back to the wall as Zoe resumes covering up its familiar colour. "Okay, seriously, why repaint the walls? Isn't that overdoing it? What's wrong with green?"

Zoe looks at you hesitantly and sighs. "Jazz, I... okay, I don't think I'm supposed to tell you this, but... It's because Mom wants you to move on. She wants your room to look different because she thinks it's best for you to accept you have to start over."

You and Zoe exchange a succession of sad looks. You notice James has stopped painting and seems like he's trying to think of something to say, but he stays quiet. Hanging your head, you wander over to the front of your bed and find a bunch of your possessions lying on the floor. You pick up a metallic baseball bat and discover that, even in two hands, it feels impossibly heavy. "That better not mean you're throwing out all my stuff," you say less than assertively.

"Oh, no way," James finally speaks up. "You'd hate us forever."

"We can't keep it here, though," Zoe says. "You can't even use your sports stuff."

You concede her point by allowing the bat to drop out of your hands and land on the floor with a thud, bringing relief to your meager arm muscles.

"I guess we'll end up keeping most of it in the attic for now," James says. You realise there are probably a few things of yours James and Zoe would like to keep for themselves, so you appreciate their refraining from doing so.

"Fine," you sigh, "At least I'll know it's there."

Zoe walks over to the door way to look at the furniture sitting in the lobby. "What are we going to do about the computer?"

"Whoa, hey, what's that supposed to mean?" you ask defensively, hurriedly walking out in front of her.

"I'm not saying you can't have it, but... it's conspicuous, you know? And you can hardly reach it anymore, anyway. You should get a laptop or something."

"Yeah, I guess..." you yield. "Is that all?"

Zoe looks at your bookcase next. "I guess the books can stay. We'll just say you... like to challenge yourself." She leans over to inspect your collection. "And they were someone else's first."

Before you can remark on that, Ella emerges from her room and slowly weaves through your furniture to approach you. "Hey, am I allowed here yet? How's it going?" She grabs the door frame and leans sideways to look into your room. "Not bad, not bad."

"Please don't approve of it," you say. "Or anything I do."

"Aww, c'mon, I thought you stopped hating me!" Ella pouts.

"I don't hate you. I just hate everything you stand for," you half-joke.

"Well, be that way." Ella crosses her arms and turns her head away, closing her eyes. Then she opens one eye and asks, "So what did Mom have to say about your friends?"

"She wasn't much help," you say. "The only idea she had was to spend time with them before telling them."

"Ooh, that could be fun..." Ella grins.

"Aaand now I know it's a bad idea," you deadpan.

"Well, we need to do something - got any better ideas?" Ella asks.

You don't. You can only hope James or Zoe will.

1111121121121212222211111122122112211112.content:
Ten minutes later you are, against your better judgement, watching as Zoe picks up the phone to call your girlfriend... or rather your former girlfriend, since she wouldn't likely be interested in dating a five-year-old girl. You know Chelsea has served as a babysitter in the past - a couple times you were called on to keep her company while she watched some brat - so she can probably be convinced to look after "Jasmine" for a while. But that's the only part of this plan you feel confident about.

"I can't believe we're doing this," you grumble, putting a hand to your forehead.

"Well, if this is a bad idea, what's a good one, huh?" Ella inquires.

"I don't think there are any good ideas," James says. "This is gonna suck however you do it."

Zoe starts talking into the phone. "Hello, Chelsea? ... He's still sick. Actually, we were wondering if you could do us a favour. Our little cousin Jasmine is staying over, but we could use someone to watch her for a while... Yeah, see, I need to keep an eye on Jazz, he's in pretty bad shape. Don't want the kid getting in the way, and everyone else is gonna be busy... can we leave her with you for a few hours? ... Alright. Oh, I'm sure he'll be fine. Thanks." She hangs up. "Okay, uh... she sounded kind of annoyed, but she'll do it."

"Great," you groan.

"Listen, here's the plan," Zoe says. "We're gonna ease her into the idea by letting her figure it out herself. So don't bother putting on too much of an act. Pretend you want to tell her, but you're not allowed to."

"So what, I should try to make her go 'hey, are you actually Jazz'?" you ask disdainfully.

"Well, I mean, she probably won't say anything," Zoe shrugs. "Just put the idea in her head, you know?"

"Alright then! Just gimme a minute," Ella says, and heads up the stairs.

Once she's out of earshot you whine, "Do I have to go with her?"

"It's that or she stays and helps with your room," James answers.

"She's only walking you there," Zoe adds. "There's no way she can mess things up... I think. She's surprised me before..."

"Thanks for the reassurance," you gripe.

After a short wait, Ella comes back downstairs - as usual, moving in her cheerfully girly way like there's nothing wrong. "Let's go, sis!" she says.

"What are you so happy about?" you mutter.

Ella pats you on the head. "Aw, you'll be fine!"

She opens the door and steps outside. You start to follow her, but turn back to say to James and Zoe, "If you toss out any of my stuff, I'll strangle you both!"

"How?" James chuckles.

"I'll find a stepladder!" You barely resist the urge to punctuate your retort by sticking out your tongue.

You reach for the door handle, but Ella grabs it first and closes the door for you. You want to complain, but you know it wouldn't make much sense. "Thanks, I guess," you say.

"No problem!" Ella beams as the two of you walk out into the street. "Sooo... how's school been, huh?"

You grunt, and try to think of a way to shut her up before realising you have an actual excuse not to talk: "We shouldn't discuss that in public."

"Aw, alright," Ella pouts.

You walk in silence to Chelsea's house, where Ella knocks on the door and, as soon as Chelsea opens it, greets her with "Hi there!"

"Yeah, hi..." Chelsea unenthusiastically replies. "Wait, are you the same one who called me?"

"Um..." Ella falters, unsure if Zoe meant to impersonate her or not. You, however, are quite sure she didn't, and never would. Sometimes you wonder whether Zoe would be as boyish if she hadn't so hated being mistaken for Ella when the two of them were younger.

"Whatever. So this is the kid?" Chelsea kneels down to be at eye level with you. "Oh, you are a cute little thing, aren't you?"

You avoid eye contact, trying to hide your anguish at seeing her from this perspective and comprehending that you may never be with her the same way again. Still, the smile on her face is something. At least she still finds you cute... just a different kind of cute. "What's the matter?" she coos. "I don't bite!"

"C'mon, Jasmine, say hi to Chelsea," Ella says, giving you a little push. But you can't quite bring yourself to speak, so you just walk inside and stand behind Chelsea.

"Quiet kid, huh?" Chelsea remarks. "Guess I can't complain."

"I'm sure she'll warm up to you," Ella replies. "Well, I gotta go! Have fun!"

Ella starts to leave, but Chelsea calls after her, "Hey..."

Ella turns her head back. "Yeah?"

"Are you sure it's just the flu Jazz has?" Chelsea asks, concern rising in her voice.

Chelsea probably wouldn't notice, but Ella seems a bit taken aback by the question. "Uhm, yeah, pretty sure... why?"

"I heard he got some concoction spilled on him during that field trip... could that be what made him sick?"

"O-oh, I'm sure that was nothing," Ella asserts with a nervous smile and a dismissive wave of her hand. "I mean, those scientists wouldn't just leave anything dangerous lying around, right?"

"Yeah, I guess you're right..." Chelsea says. "Well, tell him I miss him."

"Oh, that's sweet. I will. See you later!"

As Ella skips off you wonder... Chelsea knows you had something spilled on you, but does she know what it was?
1111121121121212222211111122122112211112.title: From girlfriend to babysitter

choices: Chelsea decided to stick by you and help
1111121121121212222211111122122112211112.content:
You settled in the living room on one of the couches and watched as Chelsea fluffed a few of the cushions on the other seats. This was an awkward moment in which neither of you spoke. As Chelsea continued her mundane and unnecessary task, you sat, a little uncomfortably, and not really thinking about it, tugged at the hem of your dress.

You really did not know how to relate to this attractive girl whom, you realized with a little blush of embarrassment, you were still crazy for. It was a little awkward for you to be in the same room with this girl and not actually pawing her. As Jasper, you would have, by now, be stealing kisses after only a brief conversation. That was what you usually did alone together. Now, as Jasmine, you had to fight hard to dismiss any amorous thoughts from your head. "This sucks", you muttered.

Chelsea stopped fluffing cushions and sat down on the other end of the couch you were on. "So, Jasmine, where're you from?" , she asked.

"Idaho", you said without thinking.

"Idaho, ....really? How long are you here for?" , she asked, a little more interested.

"Uuummm, just for a short while.....not sure how long though", you replied. Actually, you had not thought of this before but you remembered that Zoe had asked you to pretend to want to tell her about what has happened but not allowed. This question actually threw you off and having to lie like this was a little unsettling, but you were prepared to wing it, if necessary.

"What did your mom say?", Chelsea asked.

"Huh?", you sputtered, momentarily disoriented by the question.

"..About how long you will be staying by Jazz.", Chelsea clarified.

"Ooohh, that...well...uhmm, you know she kinda didn't say anything...", you started but Chelsea interrupted.

"You know, I really can't believe that any mom would have left her little girl with anyone without saying for how long, especially when school is still on. Don't you miss your school? Is this an extended vacation? Why would you be still there and not back home in Idaho? You really don't strike me as someone from Idaho anyway.", Chelsea rattled.

You were taken aback to her flurry of questions and remarks, to which she clearly did not give you a chance to respond. It seemed that Chelsea was not really buying what you were telling her.

Chelsea leaned closer and said, almost in a whisper, "Tell me, what is really going on over there. I can't seem to get to Jazz, and every time I called he's sick. Frankly I'm getting a little wary of that since from as long as I've known him, Jasper Storms has never been sick a day in his life, so what gives?"

You said nothing for a few minutes as you reflected on the truth of her last statement, you have never been sick as far as you could remember so you couldn't really blame Chelsea now for suspecting your prolonged bout with the "flu".

"O.K. Chelsea, I really shouldn't tell you this, but...well....uuhhm, you see, it's a bit complicated...", you faltered.

"Just spit it out!", Chelsea said, impatiently.

"Well, first of all, I'm not from Idaho...", you said, hesitantly.

"I knew it!", Chelsea said triumphantly, "...So where are you really from?, and don't lie this time..".

"I'd rather not say quite yet. But about Jazz....", you started to reply.

"Yeah, what about Jazz?", Chelsea asked, her curiosity properly aroused.

"You remember that field trip?", you asked, hoping that this would be enough for Chelsea to make certain connections about what made you sick.

"Yeah...they said that something spilled on Jazz. ....Is that what's making him sick?", Chelsea asked, realization in her voice.

"Yes, yes that's it....that's why I'm, ....uhm... he's sick!", you said, a little relieved.

"How's he sick, Jasmine? Tell me, please...", Chelsea pleaded.

"Um,.. What did they say about the thing that spilled on Jazz?", you asked, feigning interest. You actually knew the answer but you wanted Chelsea to confirm to you what she knew.

"I'm not sure, but according to Nathan and the other guys they were saying some nonsense about the liquid turning boys into girls...", she said, and stopped suddenly. She looked at you closely and you in turn looked her in the eyes with what you hoped was enough assurance for your girlfriend to finally realize who she was speaking with.

"Oohh, Mmyyy God!", Chelsea exclaimed, jumping backwards from her seat, realization finally hitting. "Jasmine....Jasper.....Jasmine...Jazz.. not from Idaho, but here, not on vacation...., You're Jazz????!!"

"Yes, I am Chelsea...you know how I wanted...", you started, but Chelsea was already a little hysterical.

"No, this can't be. How could you be Jazz???, You 're so small!....No, it's impossible! I can't believe this!", she continued. You were a little alarmed at her growing hysteria. What if she passed out? What would you do? What could you do?

"Chelsea....", you said, sliding closer and reaching for her but Chelsea was backing further away.

"Chelsea, please...hear me out...", you tried to say.

"No! I can't believe your mom and sisters would pull this on me! What were they thinking, making me babysit.. Ohh God, I don't even want to say it!...", Chelsea wailed.

"...babysit your boyfriend who is a girl!", you finished. You stood up as tall as you could and looked at Chelsea as she flopped down on the couch on the opposite side of where you were both sitting only moments before.

"Look..., you think this is all fun and games for me?? How would you feel if you wake up the morning after that stupid field trip to find that you've changed so much?", you said in frustration.

Chelsea was quiet for a moment as she tried to come to grips with what she has just confirmed. You sat down heavily on the couch, despondent that you may be losing the one girl you really cared about. You wished that if a break up was to occur it would have been on account of some indiscretion on your part and not as a result of this freakish "accident" which was getting more and more difficult to explain.

Chelsea sighed, "Jazz....I'd heard something from Nathan before but I didn't want to believe. But now....what do we do? What do we do now?"

You smiled, at least this was not a break-up, not just yet anyway.

"....I don't know Chelsea, I don't know...", you replied.
1111121121121212222211111122122112211112.title: She knows - she's been talking to Nathan, a...

1111121121121212222211111122122112211112.content:
Zoe and James were already busy making minor changes to your room. Both were moving your book shelf from the room. "Hey guys, what are you doing to my room?", you asked.

"We thought we should go ahead and do some fixes to make it more comfortable for you, you know, you being a girl and all.", James replied.

"Yeah Jazz, you could really use smaller furniture, since you're no longer over six feet..", Zoe remarked.

You pondered the irony of her remark as you realized that indeed, you were now too small for the things that you used to take for granted, including the now too big book shelf that was perfect for your many books.

"Hey, not my hoop!", you yelled as Zoe reached up to tug at the basket ball hoop hanging from your door.

"Come on Jazz, you don't really think you can keep this in here do you?," Zoe responded with a laugh, "Look how high it is from you, you'll just have to let us take it down since you may not need it all that much...", she continued. You interjected, "But Zoe, don't you think its a little too much to take away some of the things that remind me of who I am, um, was?", you pleaded.

Zoe sighed, "Oh OK, I'll let this stay, for now..", she relented. You looked around your room for anything else that was already removed and any new item that your siblings have put in the room. You noticed for the first time that they had put in a baby table and chair in one corner of the room, and your regular sized desk and chair were missing. "You gotta be kidding me guys!...", you exclaimed. "Why not just put a crib in here while you are at it!", you pouted.

"Hey that's a good idea Jazz. In fact I can get that one from the attic right now..", Zoe laughed and as James joined in laughter, you felt your face beginning to flush with embarrassment. "Come on guys, quit playing around. I'm serious, I don't want this baby stuff in here. Get my chair and desk back in here!", you practically screamed.

"Oooohhh, Jazz is getting a twemper... ", James teased.

"Yeah Jazz, lighten up. We're doing you a favor by re-arranging your room for you to be more comfortable.", Zoe said. "Where should we put stuffed toys, James?...", Zoe asked coyly.

"We could put it over there..", James replied, pointing to the corner where you normally pile your basket balls, base ball bats, roller blades, and stuff.

You stamped your foot in protest and yelled, "Hell No! Don't you dare touch my stuff! ...And I don't want any stuffed toys in here!!!"

"We better do as he says Zoe, lets leave those alone and just finish up with this book shelf", James said as you marched over to the pile of sports stuff in an attempt to block any move by either sibling to touch them.

"Yeah, I see we're gonna have a problem here.", Zoe agreed.

"Good!", you said, with some satisfaction with your apparent victory.

Ella entered the room, her arms laden with stuffed toys, "Hey guys, where should I put these?", she asked, her voice brimming with excitement.

"Um, sis, we changed our minds, we don't need any stuffed toys in here..", James replied.

Ella stopped, and looking at you said, a little crestfallen, "Why don't you want any of these cute fuzzy toys in here Jazzy?...Is it about that thing I did to you earlier? I thought I said "sorry" for pulling the ballerina on you..", she continued.

"I don't wanna have stuffed toys here!", you yelled, pushing Ella back through the door. "H-hey, watch it twerp!", Ella yelled as Zoe and James laughed.

You were interrupted by mom who came to the landing on top of the stairs, a little breathless from climbing the stairs, "Jazz, you have a visitor downstairs but I didn't say anything about your current, um, situation. I'll leave it up to you how you will handle it."

You were curious to know who it was that has come to visit and was a little peeved that whoever it was did not think to call first. You cautiously crept down the stairs, your mom and siblings close behind. You stopped abruptly just before your visitor could see you at that section of the stairs where anyone sitting in the family room could have seen you. You gasped in alarm as you saw that the person sitting on the sofa waiting a little impatiently was...
1111121121121212222211111122122112211112.title: just doing minor changes to your room

choices: mom takes you with her when she goes to work
1111121121121212222211111122122112211112.content:
Mom grimanced. All her engeries had been directed into seing that you was turned back to normal, but she didn't plan on this becoming the new normal. As for you, you've already imagining the reaction of the rest of your class when the see you walk in and take your seat. The same fear you had at the mall when Nathan approached began to build up within you. You started yelling out things a 16 year old would know

"I can't have you going to school right now. They'll be expecting a teenage boy, not a little girl" mom said. You could tell she was starting to think of other things, like your records. Basically anything confirming you're now Jasmine Storm.

Ella pouted, not liking the idea you're going to be off school for a while. "Why don't you...' she started to say, but a swift nudge from Zoe ended whatever she was going to say. you hoped she wasn't going to say that you should be sent to kindergarten. "its not like Jazz will be needing school for a very long time."

"I hope so" mom thought. She was unsure just how much of a mental change had occured, but you seemed to be okay. For the moment. "Okay, until I can get Jazz's new identity set up, she will be off school" mom announced. A slight grin formed on your face, but it falls flat when mom said that you can't stay home.

"Why?" you asked.

"Jasmine, you're five years old. You brother and sisters have to go to school and I have to go to work. While you may be smarter than nearly all girls your age, you're still a little girl."

"But mom" you whined.
1111121121121212222211111122122112211112.title: Mom keeps you home

choices: Someone overhears Mom talking about what happened to you.
After work, Mom takes you to the lab for mental tests.
1111121121121212222211111122122112211112.content:
"What am I going to do with you..." Mom mutters, putting her hand to her chin as she walks into the kitchen with the you and your siblings in tow.

Ella perks up, and in your head you scream at her to shut up as she suggests, "You could leave her at Lily's house!" Thankfully, Mom seems to ignore her, and holds her thoughtful pose for a short while longer.

"Tell you what, Jazz," she eventually says, "Just this once, I'll take you in to work with me."

You let out the breath you were holding. Finally, you get a break from Ella's whims.

"You can do that?" James asks.

Mom smiles knowingly. "I'm the manager, honey. I could get away with worse. Besides," she directs her smile at you now, "Who would complain? I'm sure my coworkers will love you."

"Mom..." you groan.

Mom clears her throat. "I should have time to make some calls during work, see what we're supposed to be doing. With any luck, by the end of today we should have a better idea of what's going to happen. The rest of you, get yourselves ready for school."

You watch your siblings' expressions as they funnel out of the room. Ella shoots you a glare, Zoe looks concerned, and James offers a supportive smile. You wait a few moments for them to get away before heading off to your room to get dressed.


Forty minutes later, Mom is taking you by the hand into the office building where she works. You've never been here before, so it's interesting to see. The place sure is nice looking, which makes sense, given that it's where Mom makes the kind of money she needs to comfortably raise four children on her own.

"Morning, Becca," the receptionist greets your mom. "Oh! Who's this?" Her eyes light up as she leans over her desk to get a good look at you. You can't help but stare up at her in a way she'll probably find endearing.

"This is Jasmine," Mom says. "I'm looking after her for a friend who couldn't find a babysitter." There's no hesitation in her voice; she must have gone over this in her head.

"Aw, she's just the cutest thing!" the receptionist gushes. You give her an unamused look, but she just giggles and pats you on the head.

Mom takes you upstairs via the elevator, and you try to ignore the curious looks of several employees as she leads you over to her office, which is separated from the cubicle area by glass panelling. You manage to get inside and retreat to a corner just as another of Mom's coworkers approaches her and prompts her to repeat her little cover story.

Afterwards, Mom sits down at her desk and, after doing a few largely inscrutable things on the computer, picks up the phone and calls someone. "Hello, this is Rebecca Storms," she says. "I need to talk about making arrangements for Jasmine? ... Yes. ... That's not... look, never mind that. ... Okay. ... Okay, I'll do that..."

She hangs up. Well, that didn't tell you much. "Mom?" you say.

"Sorry, Jazz, I can't talk much," she says, typing away on her keyboard. "Between doing my job and getting you sorted out, I'm going to be busy today."

As you let out a little moan of reluctant agreement, you look outside the office and notice that people are frequently making glances at you. Unnerved, you move around trying unsuccessfully to escape everyone's sight, until you look for a hiding place and realise that being as small as you are, you could comfortably fit beneath Mom's desk.

You sit down on the floor and shuffle backwards into the space under the desk. Once you're in there you can't see Mom's face, but she makes a little half-laugh sound that suggests she finds your behaviour cute. You're not all that concerned about embarrassing yourself right now, though. You just want to be left alone, and it feels nice and safe down here.

Mom goes on to make several more calls. You can't tell who she's talking to, but she repeats herself a lot and seems to grow increasingly frustrated with the level of bureaucracy she's encountering. After a while you take out your phone (which you actually brought with you for once) and play some games to pass the time. By the third time Mom has to explain your situation from scratch to someone, you're not really paying attention anymore.
1111121121121212222211111122122112211112.title: Take your daughter to work day

choices: And indeed, you breeze through the remaining exercises.
But then you start to to struggle with the harder tests.
1111121121121212222211111122122112211112.content:
After completing her umpteenth phone call, Mom finally bends down sideways to talk to you. "Jasmine? I've gotten in touch with... well, a lot of people, and I'm told the government are getting ready to set things up for you. But first we'll have to go back to the lab for tests..." Your eyes widen a little. "It's nothing scary, it's just... well, it's an IQ test, basically. They need to see how smart you still are before they'll know what to do with you."

You don't feel like you've gotten dumber, but the idea that your intelligence is being called into question has you concerned. You spend the rest of Mom's work hours, which feels like an eternity, worrying that these government people will find some reason to have you start school over from the beginning.

When the end of the working day finally comes, Mom calls Zoe to say you won't be home for a while, which gets you thinking. It implies that Zoe has now inherited the title of "most responsible child"; you can only assume that even if you had stayed home and Mom was going to the lab by herself, she would still be calling Zoe instead of you. The thought stings, as you'd always taken a certain pride in being second-in-command of the household.

You leave the office with minimal harassment from workers, and Mom drives to the all-too-familiar laboratory building. To your displeasure, Dr. Hanson is waiting for you just inside. Next to him stands a professionally dressed woman you don't recognise.

"Ah, here you are," Dr. Hanson says. "It's about time we got this over with."

You want to say something snippy in response, but something about being a small child surrounded by adults inhibits that urge.

"Hello, Dr. Hanson," Mom says in the icy tone she keeps reserved for him.

The woman beside Dr. Hanson quickly moves to calm the conversation. "It's nice to meet you, Mrs. Storms," she says, shaking Mom's hand. "I'm Dr. Norris, on-call psychologist for the rejuvenation project. So this is Jasmine, is it? I must say, Hanson, your research certainly has produced results."

"Indeed it has," Dr. Hanson smiles smugly. Ugh, don't encourage him, you think.

"Now, come this way, please," Dr. Norris starts leading you through the corridors. "This is going to be a fairly simple process, but it's very important to get done. We need to establish the extent of the accident's impact on Jasmine's thought processes."

"Of course," Dr. Hanson bitterly adds, "We'd have more data to work with if you'd simply agreed to co-operate with us from the beginning."

"We could still sue you, you know," Mom pointedly remarks.

Dr. Hanson throws up his arms. "Of course you could. It's not as if our funding goes towards revolutionary advances in medicine or anything important like that."

As you arrive at what is apparently your destination, Dr. Norris gives Dr. Hanson an awkward "calm down" look, clearly not enjoying being associated with him. "Now, Jasmine," she says, "I'm going to need some one-on-one time with you; is that alright?" You nod. "Mrs. Storms, you can take a seat in the waiting area over there."

"Good luck, Jazz," Mom says as Dr. Norris opens the door and takes you into a small office, featuring a desk not unlike the one you just spent hours hiding underneath, with chairs on both sides.

"Up you go!" Dr. Norris lifts you up and places you in the chair in front of the desk. It's high enough that you would have had trouble climbing into it yourself, but you still, somewhat illogically, resent the treatment.

"Now then," Dr. Norris says as she sits down on the other side of the desk, "Are you comfy? You'll have to excuse Dr. Hanson, he's -"

"A jerk?" you interrupt. There you go, there's your snippy remark. But now you hate yourself for not having the courage to say it to his face.

"Now, now, that's not nice!" Dr. Norris chides you, clearly treating you as the five-year-old you appear to be.

"I'm sixteen," you assert, as a reminder to yourself as well as her.

She looks at you sadly. "I know, I know," she sighs. "But whether you can still function as a sixteen-year-old is... well, it's what we're here to find out." You offer no response beyond a sullen look, so she continues, "Okay, now, we'll start off with some simple reasoning tests. First of all..."

Dr. Norris produces from the desk drawer a series of wooden shapes and a board featuring matching holes. You frown disdainfully. "Really?"

"Sorry!" she laughs. "But we have to start from the beginning, you know. Just humour me now, and we'll work up to the more challenging activities."

Grumbling to yourself, you quickly dump the pegs into their respective holes (although you have to stretch uncomfortably to reach one of them).

"Good," Dr. Norris says, putting the board away. "I would've been really worried if you couldn't do that! Now, on to the next one..."

Dr. Norris proceeds to present you with a succession of tasks, including reading exercises and math problems, which soon become less insulting but still fail to challenge you at all. You begin to feel confident you haven't lost any brainpower...
1111121121121212222211111122122112211112.title: Mom takes you to the lab for mental tests

choices: Mom agreed to return for the paperwork
1111121121121212222211111122122112211112.content:
The tests continued and you found that you were actually mastering each task as if it was no problem at all. What Dr. Norris did not know, how would she anyway, was that you were a straight A student as a sixteen year old, so what you were being exposed to now was literally child's play.

"OK Jasmine, you have done well so far. That's good! Maybe now I should really test your vocabulary and word association.", Dr. Norris said. "All you need to do is to say the first thing that comes to your mind as I show you the picture stimuli."

You smiled, this should be simple enough, you thought. "OK Dr. Norris, I'm ready.", you said.

For the next few minutes you answered correctly when Dr. Norris presented each picture or shape to you. Oh this is a snap! you thought, I can do this with my eyes closed you smiled, a little amused. You smiled wider as the next graphic was shown and again you answered correctly.

"OK. That's enough of these tests don't you think?", Dr. Norris said. You nodded eagerly as you were feeling a little exhausted after your efforts.

"So tell me all about you. What is it like to be a girl now?", Dr. Norris asked.

You were not quite prepared for this question but you thought that this must be an important part of the test. You told the doctor everything that had happened since the field trip and how you felt at various times. You even mentioned the embarrassing episodes when you lost control of yourself and became the five year old. You could see Dr. Norris perk up at the mention of these episodes and you noticed that she made notes.

You finished your recount and Dr. Norris took a few minutes to make a few more notes before she ushered you out to your mom who was still in the waiting area.

"Is Jazz alright Doctor?", mom asked anxiously.

"Your daughter is perfectly fine Mrs. Storms", Dr. Norris replied with a reassuring smile. "I will need just a few words with Dr. Hanson and then you will be free to go.", she said.

You followed Dr. Norris back to Dr. Hanson's office where both Dr. Hanson and Dr. Blake were in conversation.

"How did the little one do?", Dr. Hanson asked. Dr. Norris did not answer immediately but looked at you again, perhaps to read any signs in your face that she may have missed earlier. You impulsively gave her a mischievous smile and a wink. Dr. Norris returned her attention to the two doctors, "I'll have to review my notes and let you have my assessment later, if that's all right with you.", she asserted. With that, she strode through the door, leaving the two doctors a little bewildered.

"Alright then", grunted Dr. Hanson, "we'll just have to let you go now. We'll get in touch with you as soon as possible with Dr. Norris' assessment and perhaps we can see what next we need to do...", he continued.

Mom interrupted, "...If we could talk by phone, that is all I would need. I'm not too keen on coming back to your lab.", she said.

"Suit yourself", Dr. Hanson retorted. "Oh, by the way, I will need to see you again anyway so that we can deal with some paperwork, nothing serious, just us taking some precautions...", he said.
1111121121121212222211111122122112211112.title: And indeed, you breeze through the remaining ex...

choices: Mom called her lawyer as soon as she returned home
At home you had an unwelcome visit from the lab
1111121121121212222211111122122112211112.content:
It was three days later and you were anxious to hear about the test results. You were in the kitchen with mom who was preparing breakfast when you asked her about the next visit to the lab.

"I really wished I didn't have to go back there", mom replied, "but you heard what Dr Hanson had said, that we needed to return for some "paperwork", as he puts it". You nodded.

"...Not sure why they would want to do that though", she continued, "I just want everything to be over and done with."

"Me too", you said.

Mom placed your breakfast on the table and you took your seat to eat. Ella and Zoe burst in, "Morning Mom, Hi jazz", they greeted. They were ready for school and were on their way out. "Have you eaten yet?", mom called after them. "We had cereal already. We gotta catch the bus!", Ella replied, just as the sound of the approaching school bus became audible. "Hey guys hurry up!", James called as he ran to the front door, "we're late already!"

"Bye mom, bye Jazz", both sisters said as they rushed toward the door to join James. You heard the bus stop and the sound of your siblings hustling to get on it.

A few minutes later, the phone rang and mom picked up. You did not hear the conversation. Mom hung up and returned to you, "that was a secretary from the doctor's office. We are being asked to come in for your results." You felt a mixture of relief and dread. I wonder what the results really are, you thought.

_______________________________________________


You were both in the waiting area of the doctor's office as neither Dr Norris nor Dr Hanson was ready to see you just yet. You idly picked up a magazine from the rack on which various magazines were neatly arranged, and flipped the pages. Nothing really interested you but you did not know what else to do while you waited. Mom herself was looking through a magazine, but you sensed that she was a little annoyed at having to wait after all.

"The doctors are ready now Mrs Storms", the secretary said, while motioning you toward the doctor's office.

You both entered and after exchanging greeting, sat in the seats in front of the large wooden desk.

"OK, lets tell you what the test results have shown", Dr Hanson started, looking over at Dr Norris. The female doctor picked up a file that was lying on the edge of the desk and after a moment, started, "Mrs Storms, we are happy to tell you that your daughter's, um, son's mental faculties are sharp as ever and you really do not have anything to worry about there."

"Great", mom said. You were relieved as you were secretly worried that there might have been some regression.

"I am a little concerned about those episodes of behavioral loss of control that Jasmine had experienced.", Dr Norris continued. You felt as though you have been kicked in the stomach and you let out an involuntary gasp. Oh no!, what if there is something else wrong with me?, you thought.

"What do you mean doctor?", mom asked.

"Just that we will have to monitor the frequency of these episodes when Jasmine behaves as a five year old.", the doctor replied.

1111121121121212222211111122122112211112.content:
They home to find several men in black, “Who are you people?!”

“Our boss would like to speak to you, our company owns the very lab which you have a problem with, perhaps we can come to a more favourable deal,” they explained and they were driven into a huge skyscraper which extended into the clouds.

She stepped into the elegant office where a middle-aged man was sitting on a chair with a mocking expression on his face, “A pleasure to make your acquaintance, my company is the owner of that lab. You can call me Brandon.”

“What the hell have you called me here for?!” she shouted.

“Calm down a minute, I’ve come to make you an offer you can’t refuse, I’ve heard much about your situation and your little problem,” he smugly said.

“This isn’t some sort of joke, you’ve destroyed my son’s life with your nonsense,” she shouted.

“Of course not, and we have a solution,” he said making her eyes light up. A couple of assistants stepped forward with a vial in a briefcase.

“Two million dollars. And a partial antidote,” he said.

“Partial? What on earth is that supposed to mean? Fix the problem!”

“Can you imagine how expensive it would be to reverse the procedure? You have my condolences for your son’s death, I mean transformation but I’m not a saint,” he explained.

“You mean you can?” She said with a sharp gleam in her eyes.

“Not only would it take over a decade of research, but the cost to us would be catastrophic,” he explained.

“I don’t care how much it costs, I want it reversed and didn’t you say there wasn’t an antidote, even a partial one?” she asked.

“That’s mainly because the antidote isn’t perfect. It will age hi- her by five to six years, however the mental effects will become ever stronger and will be remodelled further as a female brain, of course it’s your choice if you want to use it. I won’t beat around the bush here, your son as you know him is dead.
While you could keep her as she is now, you know the torture ahead of her, if you drag her through early childhood once more. Also, can your family afford to take care of another child for yet another decade? You’re a single mother, aren’t you? We can sink your company whenever we please too.”

“What?! You want to brainwash him with your mind altering drugs and how dare you talk about him as if he’s a corpse! And you dare to threaten me?” she shouted.

“Let’s put it simply. I don’t care what you do. When you leave this room, you will take your vial and your two million dollars. Not a word to a living soul. Heck, we’ll even get her birth certificates legally changed as a bonus,” he explained.

“How dare you speak to me like this!” she shouted.

“Diplomacy has failed,” The men drew their guns out of their holsters and pointed it at her, “We played nicely, however it looks like you insist on being unreasonable. I’m not giving you an offer because I’m put in a bad position by you, our company has a tremendous amount of influence.
No one will bat an eye at a few people going missing, the super-rich need us for their immortality research. Do you want your children to become our test subjects? Agree to our terms. Now.”

“You’re going to kill me and enslave my children?!” She shuddered.

“No. We are going to inject you with the drug and turn you into a lab rat along with them. I’ll say it once more. Accept our terms. Now. Or face the consequences.”

"Ella!" you hear your little brother shout as he knocks on the bathroom door. "Stop squealing in there and let me use the bathroom." Your face pales and your heart stops in horror of the voice. You did not want anyone to see you like this, especially not someone who has idolized you to this point.

"No!" you scream trying and failing to sound authoritative or even like the teenage boy you used to be. "Don't come in, James!" However, only a second later, you see the door knob turn and immediately realize that you, in your haste, had forgotten to lock the bathroom door. James breaks into the bathroom and is surprised to see a smaller girl than he was expecting from the other side.

"Who are you are why are you wearing my brother's shirt?" he asks and glares at you, the latter of which strikes fear into your heart. Only wearing your shirt as a dress, you are intimidated to find that you are now ____.
